title: The Hornet looking to sting the Pacman
text:
Why Jeff Horn thinks he can not only beat Manny Pacquiao but stop him too if their fight goes ahead an hour ago by Staff writers Source: FOX SPORTS JEFF Horn doesn’t just think he can beat Manny Pacquiao — he reckons he can stop him, too. 
The unbeaten Australian welterweight is coming off an impressive 2016 after improving to 16-0 (one draw) following stoppage wins over Randall Bailey, Rico Mueller and Ali Funeka. 
That’s help set up the increasing prospect of a fight against Pacquiao (59-6, two draws) for the future Hall of Famer’s WBO welterweight belt at Suncorp Stadium on April 23. 
“The fight is very close,” Horn told Fox Sports News 500 . “I’ve been told it’s probably more likely to get over the line than not. So it’s pretty exciting to see if Pacquiao says yes or not and when the contracts gets signed.” Jeff Horn at Suncorp Stadium, where his fight with Manny Pacquiao is set to take place. Source: News Corp Australia 
And Horn is not just looking to win but become the first fighter to knock out Pacquiao since Juan Manuel Marquez destroyed the Pacman with a single punch in 2012. 
“Yeah, definitely,” he said, adding: “He’s probably got a little bit more cautious with how he doesn’t finish guys as much either. At welterweight, he hasn’t stopped a guy for a while. I definitely think I’ve got what it takes to get him.” 
Pacquiao hasn’t stopped anyone since his TKO victory over Miguel Cotto in 2009. 
The gulf in experience between the two fighters is reflected in their ages — Horn’s 28, Pacquiao 38 — and it’s raised questions over whether the Australian is ready for the step up in class. 
Horn is unequivocal that he’s earned his shot. Pacman may fight in Australia 0:34 
“I couldn’t even tell you the amount of top 15 opponents I’ve fought in my last fights,” Horn said. “They’ve all been pretty high quality and I’ve fought some high-skill guys, some pressure-fighting guys ... I feel like I’ve versed all the styles. 
“I might not have versed as many as Pacquiao because my experience is not as much as him, but between age and experience I feel like I’m catching him — we’re equalling out a little bit.” 
As well as Horn, who only took up boxing due to being bullied as a child, feeling like he’s improving, the Aussie also feels like Pacquiao isn’t the fighter he once was. 
Pacquiao has lost three of his last eight fights and has only fought sparingly in recent years — twice last year, once in 2015, twice in 2014 and just the once again in 2013. Manny Pacquiao with his WBO welterweight belt that Jeff Horn is after. Source: AFP 
It’s a record that fails to intimidate Horn. 
“I feel like he’s lost a little bit from where he was at his peak,” Horn said. “I reckon he’s lost 10 per cent from what he used to be. I think I’ve got him at the right time as in I’m ready, I’m ready for this fight. I believe I can beat him.” 
Asked how life-changing a victory over Pacquiao would be, Horn allows himself to dream. 
“You go through little pictures in your head of what life might be like — on the beach or something. It all just depends. Life can change very quickly depending on a fight like this.”
